captions.text:
Editor Nick and I have this fun 
little in-joke we have. I ask him

what review codes are in and advice on 
what to check out, and he says, &quot;Well,

there&#39;s this thing I&#39;m pretty sure you&#39;d 
like,&quot; and I take one look at it and go,

&quot;I don&#39;t like this at all! Why are you such 
a terrible judge of these things, you fucking

moron?&quot; And then he tells me to go fuck myself and 
I call him a cunt and give him a slap and then he

kicks me in the balls and then I scream and go for 
the eye gouge and then the police get called. Oh,

the fun we have. And this whole process played 
out last week when he suggested I take a look

at our beta code for Where Winds Meet. What&#39;s 
that, a game about two flatulent people sharing

a bed back to back? &quot;No! Also, that was extremely 
weak. It&#39;s a Chinese always-online free-to-play

RPG.&quot; And already I can feel my hands making 
the eye gouge finger quotes. Not another bloody

gacha game. I went through this with Genshin 
and Wuthering Waves and Persona X. Whatever

amusement can be gleaned from the mechanics, 
narrative, and understated booby jiggles,

I can never get past the basic functioning of 
the gacha format feeling like opening an endless

succession of advent calendars in a cubicle 
plastered with flyers for Vegas prostitutes.

&quot;Ah, but this isn&#39;t a gacha game, Yahtz. It&#39;s 
actually got a solo-play focus.&quot; Free to play.

Always online. Single-player focus. Did you 
just turn over two pages at once? &quot;Alright,

it&#39;s a little bit of a gacha game, but try 
it anyway; maybe it&#39;ll win you around.&quot; It

did not win me &#39;round. But I also didn&#39;t go 
for the eye gouge. Mainly, I returned from my

adventures in Where Farts Collide in a state 
of profound bafflement. And now, listeners,

I face the difficult task of summarizing what 
the game is actually about. I say &quot;difficult&quot;

because I&#39;m not convinced the designers knew 
that. Where Winds Meet came across to me like

someone—probably someone with an awful lot 
of money—set out to make a cutting-edge video

game. And they got very excited about all the 
cool stuff they were gonna put in it. It was

gonna be a full-on open world with combat and 
stealth and horse riding and dungeon exploring,

and one mission will be a fucking deductive puzzle 
challenge out of nowhere, and so many characters

and some of them will be AI chatbots because 
why the fuck not? But then drew a massive blank

when called upon to figure out what it was all 
actually about and how the story would set things

in motion. &quot;Er... there&#39;s a hero. They&#39;re... on 
a journey.&quot; To do what, lead designer? &quot;Look,

I can&#39;t be expected to make every bloody decision. 
I&#39;ve still got to count all this money I&#39;ve got.&quot;

The prologue depicts a very handsome young Chinese 
dude who teams up with another very handsome young

Chinese dude as they go wire-fu apeshit on a 
bunch of extremely generic bad guys, and one of

the heroes is carrying a baby, who I assume is the 
baby of someone really important because of the

way he resists the urge mid-combat to use him as 
an improvised flail. Anyway, after the prologue,

we create our character, choosing from one 
of several very similar-looking attractive,

young Chinese people, and find ourselves in 
a sleepy Chinese village hanging out with a

spunky young girl. Who I initially thought 
was the baby and that we were still playing

as the dude from the prologue, the character 
creation having been some representation of

how our looks changed after a few years in 
hiding and possibly some plastic surgery. No,

I eventually deduced that we are the baby 
all grown up, oblivious to our destiny,

who is treated by everyone else in the plot as a 
greenhorn young teen even though we are clearly

an adult with unstoppable fighting skills 
and every NPC we meet looks exactly the same

age as us. The general vibe early on is that we 
wanna go off and have adventures like the heroes

of legend but we can&#39;t because we&#39;re stuck 
helping our grumpy aunt look after the farm.

Our grumpy aunt who, again, is a very attractive 
person who looks the same age as us. Then we run

into another attractive young Chinese man 
who we&#39;re supposed to think is a grizzled

old former hero because he&#39;s wearing what looks 
like a rather ineptly made false beard. And then,

after a lot of pissing about, your home village 
gets burnt down and you lose everything in that

special way that means you can still go back 
to it and do the side quests whenever you want,

and our new life of adventuring begins. So 
yeah, it&#39;s literally Star Wars: A New Hope

if you applied the Half-Life 2 Cinematic Mod 
and the first act was dragged out for three

more hours while Luke finished packing his bum 
bag. From there, we move to a new city area and

get embroiled in some nonsense involving multiple 
factions fighting over a magic bowl that dispenses

infinite coins, most of which are represented by 
attractive young Chinese people, but importantly,

some of them aren&#39;t. So I&#39;m like, &quot;Ooh, 
finally shit&#39;s hotting up,&quot; but unfortunately,

that&#39;s as far in the plot as I got. Thanks to 
some of the game&#39;s wonderful gacha-adjacent

mechanics wherein the critical path occasionally 
screeches to a halt until you sidequest your way

to a certain level and wait an actual, literal 
day, Animal Crossing style. So it&#39;s like A New

Hope if we had to stop every now and again to 
hand crank the generator running the projector.

Every 10 levels or so, you stop gaining experience 
until you hunt through the horrible overlaying

menus like a jungle explorer with a machete 
trying to find the one tiny-winy little prompt

that will teleport you to an arena for a timed 
combat challenge, after which the next 10 levels

are unlocked. And I was like, &quot;Bitch, are you 
making me take a fucking driving test to play

more of the game? How is this supposed to make 
sense within the context of the story? Is our

character daydreaming? Is this a flashback to that 
one time they got lost in a Mafia-controlled cave

network?&quot; So immersion is impossible. Every 
time you have to venture back into the menus

to try to figure out if your weapons can be 
upgraded—and if so, which of the 19 different

screens you&#39;re supposed to do it on—you&#39;re 
not an adventurer in fantasy China anymore,

you&#39;re a node on a graph in a giant, inescapable 
PowerPoint presentation. I couldn&#39;t even find the

fucking map. I had to go into the &quot;Quests&quot; menu, 
select a quest, select &quot;Show on Map,&quot; and then go,

&quot;Oh, actually, I changed my mind; deselect 
that quest, but do you mind if I stay on

this map for a bit?&quot; And that was the only 
way to figure out where the fuck I was.

Hang on. I&#39;m forgetting something. Oh yeah, 
combat. There&#39;s combat. And it&#39;s... fine,

I guess? Bit Elden Ring-y, especially in the 
very occasional boss fights, and a bit spongey

if you don&#39;t keep up with all the fucking data 
administration work that&#39;s how you keep your stuff

upgraded. Actually, it&#39;s hard to judge because 
early on, the game said, &quot;Hey, do you want parry

assistance on?&quot; And I didn&#39;t know what that meant; 
that could have been anything from a subtle icon

over incoming attacks to the game doing all the 
parries for you like a fussy dad with a science

project. Turned out what it meant was the game 
slows down and prompts you, essentially turning

parries into quick-time events, which is more 
assistance than I wanted, but I could tell the

parryable attacks were hard to read, so I 
was afraid to turn assistance off in case I

got bogged down, and I guess that&#39;s officially 
as far as my strength of character extends. I

should mention that this and much of my struggle 
to understand the plot probably comes down to

translation issues, and in the README for the beta 
I was playing, it made sure to say, &quot;Yes, we know

the English translation kinda sucks; we&#39;ll fix 
that in the proper release and everything else you

have problems with.&quot; Which leaves me in another 
difficult position. I guess I need to summarize my

feelings about Where Credit Cards Decline without 
referencing glitches, shitty menu design, bad

translation, or anything else that can be fixed in 
post. Okay then. It&#39;s shit. Thanks for watching.
